title: Dickson's Sum-Free Extension
description: Given a finite set A of positive integers, extend by always choosing the smallest integer not expressible as a sum of two previous elements. Is the difference sequence a_{m+1} − aₘ eventually periodic? An old problem of Dickson.

overview.historicalContext: This is an old problem of Dickson, highlighted by Erdős and Graham (1980, p. 53). The extension rule — always pick the smallest non-sum — creates sequences whose difference patterns appear to become periodic, but proving this remains open. Even starting from {1,4,9,16,25}, periodicity takes thousands of terms to emerge.
overview.problemStatement: For any finite starting set A, is the sequence of consecutive differences in the Dickson extension eventually periodic?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize pairwise sums, the Dickson extension sequence, the difference sequence, eventual periodicity, and structural properties including strict monotonicity and sum avoidance.
keyInsights: Each new term is the smallest integer not a sum of two previous terms
The difference sequence appears eventually periodic for all tested starting sets
Even small starting sets (perfect squares) require thousands of terms for periodicity
Featured as Problem 7 on Ben Green's open problems list
The eventual period depends on the starting set

sections.title: Core Definitions
sections.summary: Defines pairwise sums, sum representability, the Dickson extension sequence, difference sequence, and eventual periodicity.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: States the Erdős–Dickson conjecture: for every finite starting set, differences are eventually periodic.

sections.title: Structural Properties
sections.summary: Strict monotonicity, positive differences, sum avoidance, and minimality of each extension step.

sections.title: Examples and Growth
sections.summary: Singleton starting set, slow periodicity of squares, period dependence on initial set, and linear growth.

conclusion.summary: Formalizes Erdős Problem #341 (Dickson's sum-free extension): extending a finite set by always choosing the smallest non-sum creates sequences with apparently periodic differences, but proving periodicity remains open.
conclusion.implications: A proof would reveal hidden periodicity structure in additive combinatorics, connecting greedy algorithms to automatic sequences.
openQuestions: Is the difference sequence always eventually periodic?
How does the period depend on the starting set?
What is the growth rate of the period as a function of the starting set?
